The topological nature of the material is determined by the relative sign between $M_0$ and $M_2$. If the ratio between the two parameters is positive, then the insulating state is $\mathbb{Z}_2$ with topological index $\nu=0$  i.e. the material is a trivial insulator. Otherwise, one gets $\nu=1$ and the material is a strong topological insulator. The strong topological insulator has surface states protected by strong and weak disorder unlike the weak topological insulator that in presence of disorder pushes the metal surface state into the bulk, opening a gap in the Dirac cone\cite{Zohar}.

If we look at the problem of a slab of this material\cite{Wen}, new surface states appear in the gap energy around zero energy.
